title: after a seemingly unarmed black man was shot seven times from behind by a white cop, r/protectandserve is already working overtime to justify the killing

author: lame_but_endearing
text: The most downvoted comment is someone, who says they’re not even anti cop, saying that 7 shots in the back seems a bit excessive. They love brutality in that sub.

text: [deleted]

author: johnnymo1
text:
Guns are lethal weapons, not tools for immobilizing. If you're shooting at someone, things had better be at the point where you're trying to kill them outright because that's the level of force you're using.

The problem is not that he was shot 7 times, it's that he was shot at all.

author: breecher
text:
>Guns are lethal weapons, not tools for immobilizing. If you're shooting at someone, things had better be at the point where you're trying to kill them outright because that's the level of force you're using.

That's just the bullshit explanation that the American policeforce invented back in the day to justify their extrajudicial killings. You won't find this philosophy accepted by basically any other Western policeforce.

author: jorbleshi_kadeshi
text:
The way you're talking, it seems you think this stance somehow makes you harder on police, when in actuality it is a ***lot*** more lenient than it should be.

The barrier is the first shot. If you're haggling over how many times it's acceptable to shoot someone you've already given up a downright absurd amount of ground.

The number of bullets fired should either be zero (lethal force isn't warranted) or as many as is necessary to kill someone (lethal force is warranted). The threshold to cross from the first scenario to the second is so far from where it should be it's criminal. We need to move that threshold, not argue over the number of bullets.

author: thelizardkin
text: This, it's the same reason why you should never fire a warning shot. If you're not in a situation where you are not justified to potentially kill someone, you shouldn't be firing a gun at all.

author: Biffingston
text: That and a bullet doesn't magically go away because it's a warning shot.

author: itmustbeluv_luv_luv
text: German police has laws that allow warning shots. Only American police has that "shoot to kill" doctrine.

author: thelizardkin
text: The problem with warning shots, is that you shouldn't be shooting a gun unless you absolutely have to, to stop an immediate threat.

author: itmustbeluv_luv_luv
text: Exactly, and if a warning shot might stop that threat, it's a legitimate use. Shoot to kill is an American doctrine of warrior cops. Any other police force on earth is different.

author: thelizardkin
text: It's not shoot to kill, but shoot to stop. If the situation is mild enough that a warning shot is all that's required, than you shouldn't be shooting the gun at all. Warning shots put everyone around you at risk.

author: johnnymo1
text:
You could be right about the origin but I think the philosophy itself is correct in a situation where shooting is actually warranted. I see awful ideas in comments on news stories all the time like "why not just shoot them in the leg instead?" Because if you're trying not to kill someone, your gun shouldn't be involved to begin with. It engenders this weird casual idea that shooting someone isn't gonna kill them if you weren't *trying* to.

There are much more important distinctions between our police force and others, like that many of them simply don't have officers carrying guns everywhere, or never carrying until a situation requires it. I don't think "we should shoot the unarmed black man one time instead of seven" should be the actual focus of concern here.

EDIT: Granted, using that idea has clearly not kept the US police from treating guns incredibly casually, so take from that what you will

author: itmustbeluv_luv_luv
text:
Leg shots *are* legitimate means police forces in Germany use. Quote:

>Ziel eines Schusswaffengebrauchs ist u. a. die Verhinderung der Flucht von Verdächtigen oder Gefangenen und die Abwehr gegenwärtiger konkreter Gefahren für eine erhebliche Gefahr für Leib oder Leben (z. B. Amoklagen). Hierbei kann der Adressat der Maßnahme physisch geschädigt werden, z. B. durch einen Beinschuss. Dies muss jedoch nicht stets der Fall sein – die Schusswaffe kann auch gegen Sachen (Schuss in die Reifen eines flüchtenden Fahrzeuges) oder als Drohmittel (Warnschuss) gebraucht werden.

Translation:

>The aim of the use of firearms is, among other things, to prevent the escape of suspects or prisoners and to avert current concrete dangers that pose a considerable danger to life or limb (e.g. amok threats). The addressee of the measure can be physically harmed, e.g. by a leg shot. However, this does not always have to be the case - the firearm can also be used against objects (shot in the tires of a fleeing vehicle) or as a threatening device (warning shot).

author: Gh0st1y
text: So do you think that shooting someone with the intent to maim in order to de-escalate is the correct course of action in some situation, or something?

author: Lz_erk
text: How about with the intent to protect one's own life? At what point do you stop shooting anyway, when you're out of ammo?

author: jorbleshi_kadeshi
text:
> At what point do you stop shooting anyway, when you're out of ammo?

Whenever you feel that the threat to your life has been neutralized. If you're *truly* in a self-defense situation, you can use as many bullets as you need. If that means the entire magazine, that's what you gotta do. Everybody reacts to bullets differently, especially with differing body masses or different chemicals. Some people can eat bullets and still keep charging. If they have a knife you'd better be prepared to pull that trigger until they drop. And at the point where you're using lethal force, "extra" lethal force isn't really a thing. If you're worried about killing someone "too much", then you probably didn't need to kill them at all, meaning this isn't self-defense.

Again, this only applies if you're *actually* defending your life (and this is what *should* apply to police officers). Right now they can just say "I feared for my life" with a smirk and a wink and the courts say "well ok then and thank you for your service".

author: Gh0st1y
text: No, you're missing the point entirely. You use as many bullets as needed to end a threat to your life, but you don't go into that thinking "I'm just going to shoot to disable, not to kill". If you're pulling the trigger you'd better be ready to have a life on your hands because in an uncontrolled firefight -type situation there's no reliable way to just shoot to maim or disable. If you're shooting at someone in such a situation you are trying to kill them, and training any law enforcement to think any differently just seems like a quick way to raise casualty rates on all sides.

author: Selgin1
text:
Literally the first thing I learned when I fired a gun for the first time: *do not point this thing at something you're not willing to kill.*

You literally took a statement that says "don't so much as *point* a gun when it's not warranted" and claimed that it justifies extrajudicial killings.

author: Gishin
text: How is that bullshit? Guns absolutely should only be used as a last resort, when the only option left is to kill someone. If you don't need to kill someone, you don't need to shoot someone.
